title: IRC Archive for channel #xwiki on 26 March 2017 - XWiki
content:
<kikoudz[m]> has joined #xwiki  
00:57 <kikoudz[m]> has left #xwiki  
01:27 <moep> has joined #xwiki  
06:13 <sgc072> has joined #xwiki  
06:16 <sgc072> has quit  
06:37 <dmidma> Hey any quick fix for this error: Error number 4001 in 4: Error while evaluating velocity template htmlheader.vm ?  
06:42 <dmidma> Ahha, I should increase the memory in JAVA\_OPTS  
06:42 <dmidma> Stupid me ^^'  
08:24 <dmidma> has quit  
11:08 <cjd[m]> has joined #xwiki  
11:08 <cjd[m]> hey vmassol have you ever tried writing clojure ?  
11:08 <cjd[m]> I've heard that you can do the equivilant of thousands of lines of java in maybe 30 or 50 lines since it's a lisp and it runs in the jvm  
11:09 <cjd[m]> downside is its 30 or 50 lines which you need a highly capable programmer to maintain but upside is its still just 30 or 50 lines....  
11:16 <vmassol> cjd: no never tried clojure and I'm not really looking forward to :) As you say it's complex to write functional progreamming. I've done a bit of lisp and camel light during my studies. But in any case nowadays what's important is not so much the language but the ecosystem/tooling/ability to find developers. For a pet project it's fine ofc and interesting to learn from a curiosity perspective.  
11:17 <cjd[m]> I had some friends over and we were talking about roughly this problem on Friday night  
11:18 <cjd[m]> You can make your code approachable to "mediocre" developers and then really good ones won't be interested to work on it, or you can go ahead and make the code very high quality and it will not be accessible to anyone except the best but the best will enjoy working on it...  
11:19 <cjd[m]> Can do in 50 lines with a handful of macros what normally takes 500 or 600 but then you need engineers who understand macros and really get the underpinnings of the language  
11:20 <cjd[m]> old but good: https://printer-bath-38758.netlify.com/archives/654/
